fullDescription.text: A resource that is opened for writing but not closed may cause a resource leak.
Building a SQL or Java Persistence query from user-controlled sources is vulnerable to insertion of malicious code by the user.
A database resource that is opened but not closed may cause a resource leak.

shortDescription.text: Uncontrolled data used in path expression

fullDescription.text: Accessing paths influenced by users can allow an attacker to access unexpected resources.

shortDescription.text: Information exposure through a stack trace

fullDescription.text: Information from a stack trace propagates to an external user. Stack traces can unintentionally reveal implementation details that are useful to an attacker for developing a subsequent exploit.
Insecure cookies may be sent in cleartext, which makes them vulnerable to interception.

shortDescription.text: Query built without neutralizing special characters

fullDescription.text: Building a SQL or Java Persistence query without escaping or otherwise neutralizing any special characters is vulnerable to insertion of malicious code.
A resource that is opened for reading but not closed may cause a resource leak.
Using a boxed type for a variable that is never assigned 'null' hinders readability because it implies that 'null' is a potential value.
Deserializing user-controlled data may allow attackers to execute arbitrary code.
A format call with a format string that refers to fewer arguments than the number of supplied arguments will silently ignore the additional arguments.
Dereferencing a variable whose value may be 'null' may cause a 'NullPointerException'.

shortDescription.text: Resolving XML external entity in user-controlled data

fullDescription.text: Parsing user-controlled XML documents and allowing expansion of external entity references may lead to disclosure of confidential data or denial of service.
Accessing an array with an index that is greater than or equal to the length of the array causes an 'ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException'.
Disabling CSRF protection makes the application vulnerable to a Cross-Site Request Forgery (CSRF) attack.

shortDescription.text: Unused variable, import, function or class

fullDescription.text: Unused variables, imports, functions or classes may be a symptom of a bug and should be examined carefully.
If a variable is not declared as a local variable, it becomes a global variable by default, which may be unintentional and could lead to unexpected behavior.
Code that uses automatic semicolon insertion inconsistently is hard to read and maintain.
Variables should be declared before their first use.
If a conditional expression always evaluates to true or always evaluates to false, this suggests incomplete code or a logic error.
An expression that has no effect and is used in a void context is most likely redundant and may indicate a bug.
Nested expressions where the formatting contradicts the grouping enforced by operator precedence are difficult to read and may even indicate a bug.
An assignment to a local variable that is not used later on, or whose value is always overwritten, has no effect.
A loop iteration variable is unused, which suggests an error.
If an HTML document contains two elements with the same id attribute, it may be interpreted differently by different browsers.
An array index is compared to be less than or equal to the 'length' property, and then used in an indexing operation that could be out of bounds.
An unknown directive has no effect and may indicate a misspelling.
Defensive code that guards against a situation that never happens is not needed.
An assignment to a property whose value is always overwritten has no effect.

shortDescription.text: Loop iteration skipped due to shifting

fullDescription.text: Removing elements from an array while iterating over it can cause the loop to skip over some elements, unless the loop index is decremented accordingly.
